chapter3.html#presm.maction.name: maction
chapter3.html#presm.maction.summary: The following example uses the "toggle" actiontype:
chapter3.html#presm.maction.title: <maction>

chapter2.html#interf.toplevel.name: math
chapter2.html#interf.toplevel.summary: The top-level element in MathML is <math>. Every valid MathML instance must be wrapped in <math> tags. In addition you must not nest a second <math> element in another, but you can have an arbitrary number of other child elements in it.
chapter2.html#interf.toplevel.title: <math>

chapter3.html#presm.menclose.name: menclose
chapter3.html#presm.menclose.summary: The MathML <menclose> element renders its content inside an enclosing notation specified by the notation attribute.
chapter3.html#presm.menclose.title: <menclose>

chapter3.html#presm.merror.name: merror
chapter3.html#presm.merror.summary: The MathML <merror> element is used to display contents as error messages. In Firefox this error message is rendered similar to the typical XML error message. Note that this error is not thrown when your MathML markup is wrong or not well-formed XML. You will still get an XML parsing error (in case of the XHTML notation of MathML), which has nothing to do with <merror>.
chapter3.html#presm.merror.title: <merror>

chapter3.html#presm.mfrac.name: mfrac
chapter3.html#presm.mfrac.summary: The MathML <mfrac> element is used to display fractions.
chapter3.html#presm.mfrac.title: <mfrac>

chapter3.html#presm.mglyph.name: mglyph
chapter3.html#presm.mglyph.summary: The MathML <mglyph> element is used to display non-standard symbols where existing Unicode characters are not available. It may be used within token elements.
chapter3.html#presm.mglyph.title: <mglyph>

chapter3.html#presm.mi.name: mi
chapter3.html#presm.mi.summary: The MathML <mi> element indicates that the content should be rendered as an identifier such as function names, variables or symbolic constants. You can also have arbitrary text in it to mark up terms.
chapter3.html#presm.mi.title: <mi>

chapter3.html#presm.mlabeledtr.name: mlabeledtr
chapter3.html#presm.mlabeledtr.summary: The MathML <mlabeledtr> element is used to represent a label in a row either on the left or on the right side (determined using the side attribute on the <mtable> element). Child elements of <mlabeledtr> must be <mtd> elements. The first child is the label whereas all other children are representing row contents and are treated identically to children of <mtr> elements.
chapter3.html#presm.mlabeledtr.title: <mlabeledtr>

chapter3.html#presm.mmultiscripts.name: mmultiscripts
chapter3.html#presm.mmultiscripts.summary: The MathML <mmultiscripts> element allows you to create tensor-like objects. In a descriptive way tensors are multidimensional matrices (mathematical imprecise but exemplified). The degree of a tensor depends on the dimensionality of a representative array. For example, a number is a 0-dimensional array, or a 0th-order tensor. A 1-dimensional array (e.g. vectors) is a 1st-order tensor and so 2nd-order tensors are needed to represent square matrices. To learn more about the mathematical background of tensors refer to the entry on Wikipedia.
chapter3.html#presm.mmultiscripts.title: <mmultiscripts>

chapter3.html#presm.mn.name: mn
chapter3.html#presm.mn.summary: The MathML <mn> element represents a numeric literal which is normally a sequence of digits with a possible separator (a dot or a comma). However,  it is also allowed to have arbitrary text in it which is actually a numeric quantity, for example "eleven".
chapter3.html#presm.mn.title: <mn>

chapter3.html#presm.mo.name: mo
chapter3.html#presm.mo.summary: The MathML <mo> element represents an operator in a broad sense. Besides operators in strict mathematical meaning, this element also includes "operators" like parentheses, separators like comma and semicolon, or "absolute value" bars.
chapter3.html#presm.mo.title: <mo>

chapter3.html#presm.mover.name: mover
chapter3.html#presm.mover.summary: The MathML <mover> element is used to attach an accent or a limit over an expression. Use the following syntax: <mover> base overscript </mover>
chapter3.html#presm.mover.title: <mover>

chapter3.html#presm.mpadded.name: mpadded
chapter3.html#presm.mpadded.summary: The MathML <mpadded> element is used to add extra padding and to set the general adjustment of position and size of enclosed contents.

firefox.notes: <mpadded> within <mtable> is not supported before Firefox 20, see bug 459363.

chapter3.html#presm.mpadded.title: <mpadded>

chapter3.html#presm.mphantom.name: mphantom
chapter3.html#presm.mphantom.summary: The MathML <mphantom> element is rendered invisibly, but dimensions (such as height, width, and baseline position) are still kept.
chapter3.html#presm.mphantom.title: <mphantom>

chapter3.html#presm.mroot.name: mroot
chapter3.html#presm.mroot.summary: The MathML <mroot> element is used to display roots with an explicit index. Two arguments are accepted, which leads to the syntax: <mroot> base index </mroot>.
chapter3.html#presm.mroot.title: <mroot>

chapter3.html#presm.mroot.name: msqrt
chapter3.html#presm.mroot.summary: The MathML <msqrt> element is used to display square roots (no index is displayed). The square root accepts only one argument, which leads to the following syntax: <msqrt> base </msqrt>.
chapter3.html#presm.mroot.title: <msqrt>

chapter3.html#presm.mrow.name: mrow
chapter3.html#presm.mrow.summary: The MathML <mrow> element is used to group sub-expressions, which usually contain one or more operators with their respective operands (such as <mi> and <mn>). This element renders as a horizontal row containing its arguments.
chapter3.html#presm.mrow.title: <mrow>

chapter3.html#presm.ms.name: ms
chapter3.html#presm.ms.summary: The MathML <ms> element represents a string literal meant to be interpreted by programming languages and computer algebra systems. By default, string literals are displayed as enclosed by double quotes ("); by using the lquote and rquote attributes, you can set custom characters to display. Note that quotation marks should not be specified unless they are part of the string literal. The content of an <ms> element is not an ASCII string per se, but rather a sequence of characters and <mglyph> and <malignmark> elements.
chapter3.html#presm.ms.title: <ms>

chapter3.html#presm.mspace.name: mspace
chapter3.html#presm.mspace.summary: The MathML <mspace> element is used to display a blank space, whose size is set by its attributes.
chapter3.html#presm.mspace.title: <mspace>

chapter3.html#presm.mstyle.name: mstyle
chapter3.html#presm.mstyle.summary: The MathML <mstyle> element is used change the style of its children. It accepts all attributes of all MathML presentation elements with some exceptions and additional attributes listed below.
chapter3.html#presm.mstyle.title: <mstyle>

chapter3.html#presm.msub.name: msub
chapter3.html#presm.msub.summary: The MathML <msub> element is used to attach a subscript to an expression.
chapter3.html#presm.msub.title: <msub>

chapter3.html#presm.msubsup.name: msubsup
chapter3.html#presm.msubsup.summary: The MathML <msubsup> element is used to attach both a subscript and a superscript, together, to an expression.
chapter3.html#presm.msubsup.title: <msubsup>

chapter3.html#presm.msup.name: msup
chapter3.html#presm.msup.summary: The MathML <msup> element is used to attach a superscript to an expression.
chapter3.html#presm.msup.title: <msup>

chapter3.html#presm.mtable.name: mtable
chapter3.html#presm.mtable.summary: The MathML <mtable> element allows you to create tables or matrices. Inside a <mtable> only <mtr> and <mtd> elements may appear. These elements are similar to <table> , <tr> and <td> elements of HTML.
chapter3.html#presm.mtable.title: <mtable>

chapter3.html#presm.mtd.name: mtd
chapter3.html#presm.mtd.summary: The MathML <mtd> element represents a cell in a table or a matrix. It may only appear in a <mtr> element. This element is similar to the <td> element of HTML.
chapter3.html#presm.mtd.title: <mtd>

chapter3.html#presm.mtext.name: mtext
chapter3.html#presm.mtext.summary: The MathML  element is used to render arbitrary text with no notational meaning, such as comments or annotations.
chapter3.html#presm.mtext.title: <mtext>

chapter3.html#presm.mtr.name: mtr
chapter3.html#presm.mtr.summary: The MathML <mtr> element represents a row in a table or a matrix. It may only appear in a <mtable> element. This element is similar to the <tr> element of HTML.
chapter3.html#presm.mtr.title: <mtr>

chapter3.html#presm.munder.name: munder
chapter3.html#presm.munder.summary: The MathML <munder> element is used to attach an accent or a limit under an expression. It uses the following syntax: <munder> base underscript </munder>
chapter3.html#presm.munder.title: <munder>

chapter3.html#presm.munderover.name: munderover
chapter3.html#presm.munderover.summary: The MathML <munderover> element is used to attach accents or limits both under and over an expression.
chapter3.html#presm.munderover.title: <munderover>
